articles.headline: Low-Interest Auto Loans, Thanks to the European Central Bank
articles.snippet: Automakers on the Continent are using money borrowed from the central bank’s stimulus program to offer low-interest loans to customers.
articles.abstract: Automakers on the Continent are using money borrowed from the central bank’s stimulus program to offer low-interest loans to customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As it moved boldly in recent months to avert a credit squeeze and a rash of bank failures, the European Central Bank might also have subsidized the market rollout of Volkswagen’s newest subcompact.

articles.headline: A Wall St. Firm Advises Greece, With Discretion
articles.snippet: BlackRock is helping determine how much capital Greek banks need to raise in the coming months, a crucial step as Greece tries to fix its banking industry and its broader economy, but a risky one.
articles.abstract: BlackRock is helping determine how much capital Greek banks need to raise in the coming months, a crucial step as Greece tries to fix its banking industry and its broader economy, but a risky one.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In unmarked offices here on a dusty block choked with strip clubs and burned-out buildings, several dozen employees of a Wall Street firm spent months poring over bank loan portfolios as Greece struggled with its debt crisis.

articles.headline: U.S. War Game Sees Perils of Israeli Strike Against Iran
articles.snippet: A classified war game held this month forecast that such an attack would lead to a wider regional war, which could draw in the United States, officials said.
articles.abstract: A classified war game held this month forecast that such an attack would lead to a wider regional war, which could draw in the United States, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A classified war simulation held this month to assess the repercussions of an Israeli attack on Iran forecasts that the strike would lead to a wider regional war, which could draw in the United States and leave hundreds of Americans dead, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Report on Ousted China Official Shows Effort at Damage Control
articles.snippet: New details about the sacking of a powerful party chief amid a corruption scandal provide a rare glimpse of the government’s internal efforts to manage one of its biggest political earthquakes in years.
articles.abstract: New details about the sacking of a powerful party chief amid a corruption scandal provide a rare glimpse of the government’s internal efforts to manage one of its biggest political earthquakes in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Communist Party leaders sacked Bo Xilai, the powerful party chief of metropolitan Chongqing, after being told that he had schemed to remove his police chief and impede a corruption investigation involving his family, according to a preliminary report on Mr. Bo’s actions circulated among government officials.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: At Heart of Health Law Clash, a 1942 Case of a Farmer’s Wheat
articles.snippet: Both sides believe that a 70-year-old precedent involving the Constitution’s commerce clause supports their arguments.
articles.abstract: Both sides believe that a 70-year-old precedent involving the Constitution’s commerce clause supports their arguments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the Obama administration persuades the Supreme Court to uphold its health care overhaul law, it will be in large part thanks to a 70-year-old precedent involving an Ohio farmer named Roscoe C. Filburn.

articles.headline: Automation Is Considered for Checking IDs in Airports
articles.snippet: Agents now visually check boarding passes against IDs in American airports. Soon, machines may do it.
articles.abstract: Agents now visually check boarding passes against IDs in American airports. Soon, machines may do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration has spent a lot of money on technology to keep dangerous items off planes — with mixed results — but has been slower to address another risk: travelers who are using a fake boarding pass or identification.

articles.headline: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps
articles.snippet: When Google included smaller Web sites in the fees it charges to incorporate its maps online, many of them rebelled.
articles.abstract: When Google included smaller Web sites in the fees it charges to incorporate its maps online, many of them rebelled.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory.

articles.headline: For 2nd Year, a Sharp Drop in Law School Entrance Tests
articles.snippet: The Law School Admission Test was administered 16 percent fewer times than a year ago, the largest decline in more than a decade.
articles.abstract: The Law School Admission Test was administered 16 percent fewer times than a year ago, the largest decline in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Legal diplomas are apparently losing luster.

articles.headline: Use of ‘Conflict Minerals’ Gets More Scrutiny From U.S.
articles.snippet: Certain minerals, mined in strife-torn Africa and used in products like cellphones, are part of a debate before the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: Certain minerals, mined in strife-torn Africa and used in products like cellphones, are part of a debate before the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An iPhone can do a lot of things. But can it arm Congolese rebels?

articles.headline: A Florida Law Gets Scrutiny After a Teenager’s Killing
articles.snippet: Seven years after Florida adopted the “Stand Your Ground” law, the shooting of Trayvon Martin, who was unarmed, has put that law at the center of an increasingly angry debate.
articles.abstract: Seven years after Florida adopted the “Stand Your Ground” law, the shooting of Trayvon Martin, who was unarmed, has put that law at the center of an increasingly angry debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Seven years after Florida adopted its sweeping self-defense law, the shooting of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, has put that law at the center of an increasingly angry debate over how he was killed and whether law enforcement officers have the authority to charge the man who killed him.
